Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: In Situ Mitigation of Dendrite Formation in Lithium Metal Batteries Using Software and Electronics
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) project is the creation of a control system that enables the next generation of high capacity lithium metal batteries to replace current lithium ion battery technology. The global lithium-ion battery market is expected to grow to $67.70 billion USD by end of 2022 from $31.17 billion USD in 2016. However, lithium ion batteries cannot store sufficient energy required by the applications contributing most to that growth (i.e., electric vehicles) as demonstrated by the slow adoption within the largest battery powered product markets today. Lithium metal batteries were conceived decades ago and are capable of storing three times the energy of lithium ion batteries. Yet inherent chemical instability renders them extremely dangerous to recharge, preventing their use. This project is the next phase of work to develop a system that monitors and maintains the stability of lithium metal batteries during charging, enabling safe and reliable use by consumers, businesses, and government. The complete solution will consist of licensable hardware and software which can be tailored to specific battery powered applications, integrating with battery cells or charging systems for consumer electronics, long range electric vehicles, medical devices, and grid storage systems.

This SBIR Phase I project funds the continued development of a new paradigm in battery healing: maintaining battery electrode health from the outside in. The system uses software and electronics that control surface issues on battery electrodes which otherwise cause permanent loss of capacity and life during normal use. As an important part of the overall solution being developed, the key technical hurdles addressed by this proposed SBIR project are focused on real-time electrode surface sensing and mapping capabilities and control strategies to suppress dendrites, as well as advanced characterization methods to monitor and share electrode health information with other components to ensure safety, reliability and durability of the overall energy storage system. The R&D plan will include development of live mapping of electrochemically active surfaces, control software to develop an algorithm and feedback system, and machine learning to improve sensing-mapping-control strategies. The most promising set of solutions will be demonstrated and validated in an operando visualization test cell that allows observation of the formation and suppression of dendrites on lithium metal electrodes.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Available lithium ion battery technologies are falling short of the US Department of Energy's cost, performance and safety objectives. Adoption of electric vehicles remains low as a result of impractical driving ranges and charging times caused by low energy density and intentionally oversized battery packs designed to prevent safety issues and enable an eight-year battery life.  Replacement of graphite with pure lithium as lithium metal anodes is urgently needed for batteries to continue enabling compelling products while meeting multiple market-driven requirements of <$100/kWh, 400-mile driving ranges and <10 minute charging times. 

The primary obstacle to achieving these objectives is the immediate formation of mossy and needle-like roughness on the anode, frequently in the form of dendritic structures, during charging cycles. Dendrite growth on the lithium metal anode leads to erratic voltage and rapid failure in ten or fewer charging cycles as the operating voltage decreases, shorting occurs and heat builds up with the potential for dangerous outcomes.  Though currently lithium metal batteries are significantly more prone to failure than lithium ion batteries, their enablement would result in up to 10x increase in energy density for electronics, transportation and grid storage.  This requires an effective approach to stabilizing the anode surface.

Alligant Scientific has developed a prototype of the primary Phase 1 deliverable: Software and hardware for sensing the internal state of a battery and adaptively controlling the anode condition during charging.  Initial focus was on control of dendrite growth across zinc anodes as a pre-step to working with lithium.  Similar to lithium, rechargeable zinc metal batteries are hindered by the growth of dendrites.  Zinc is less expensive than lithium and its ease of use allowed high-throughput experimentation and the rapid development of Alligant's solution.  Important process benefits, including repeatable control, prevention of electrode roughening, improved plating uniformity and controlled orientation of plated grain structure were validated by sub-awardees at the University of Michigan using zinc.

Important to the comparison of dendrite growth on zinc and lithium is the shared correlation between small grain size and dendrite proliferation. Lithium dendrites are comprised of small grains that follow 3D growth patterns due largely to electrolyte decomposition which forms the SEI layer.  Smaller grains yield a higher surface area and increased interfacial area with the electrolyte.  Consequently, well established mechanisms of roughness formation due to electrolyte decomposition with lithium are enhanced and tend to dominate surface activity. These growths may be compared to the mossy zinc dendrites that develop during plating without Alligant's process (Figure 1).  Shown using 3D microscopy, dendrites exceeding 1mm height evolve among crystalline zinc due to the decomposition of aqueous zinc electrolyte. While there are obvious mechanistic and behavioral differences between lithium and zinc, this example provides a relatively simple and relevant basis of comparison between the two.

Analysis of deposited zinc electrodes on a copper current collector with and without Alligant's process is shown in Figure 2.  After 8 hours of charging activity, the sample treated with Alligant's process remains free of large, mossy dendrites and maintains a smooth surface roughness distribution.  Analysis from the University of Michigan (Phase 1 sub-awardee) provides a closer look at the surface structure as well as validation of the transferability of the process.  Figure 3 uses optical and scanning electron microscopy to compare plating of zinc onto copper with and without Alligant's treatment.  The treated sample remains free of rough growths with the potential to propagate as dendrites or other forms of surface roughness detrimental to battery performance.

Work performed during Phase 1 by Alligant and the Dasgupta Group at the University of Michigan has successfully confirmed the capability of Alligant's technology to suppress anode surface roughness by eliminating 90% of the peaks found on the non-Alligant samples, including dendrites, as well as eliminating >85% of unplated/nonuniformly plated space on the anode surface. Using the platform developments achieved during Phase 1, experimentation is now underway with lithium metal and lithium ion batteries to develop stable, lithium electrodes as well as to stabilize lithium ion electrodes under severe conditions such as fast charging and deep discharge.

The advancements made during Phase 1 can be applied to many applications.  Rechargeable zinc batteries also require dendrite suppression to achieve energy-dense design and market readiness.  A variety of industrially significant plating and coating processes using copper, aluminum, nickel, etc. also have smoothness requirements that would be improved by using Alligant's technology.  Copper plating is especially relevant to the manufacture of printed circuit boards (PCBs), for which smooth deposits are maintained using chemical additives that impact the quality and cost of the deposit.  Zinc is a common coating used for corrosion suppression across many industries, including auto and aviation parts, oil and gas, construction and manufacturing operations. These represent additional breadth of applications, in addition to enabling superior lithium metal batteries, which can benefit from Alligant's technology.
